awd_titl_txt: Travel Grant: MIDWEST MACHINE LEARNING SYMPOSIUM 2024
awd_abstract_narration:
The PIs propose a travel grant program to provide support for graduate students from US universities to attend the Midwest Machine Learning symposium (MMLS) 2024 on May 20-21, 2024 . The objective of this grant is to provide travel support for graduate students enrolled in US universities to present posters and participate in the conference. The PIs, representing the conference organizing committee, are requesting  to support the travels of up to 20 graduate students for roundtrip airfare and to provide for student lodging up to 150 students  for two nights (first come first serve) at the Univ. of Minnesota. The travel grants will be awarded competitively to graduate students from US universities. The awardees will be selected by a committee chosen by the organizing committee and the poster quality will be considered in the selection process. The awards will be administered by University Minnesota, with no overhead to be charged.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
The Midwest Machine Learning Symposium (MMLS) is an annual regional conference dedicated to fostering collaboration among researchers in the Midwest and beyond. MMLS 2024 was held on May 20–21 at the University of Minnesota Twin Cities campus, MN. The event attracted over 350 participants, including graduate students, faculty, and industry professionals, providing a platform for discussing cutting-edge research in machine learning and data science, both foundational and applied. 

MMLS features 4 plenary talks by leading researchers, 20+ invited talks by junior faculty and industrial researchers from Midwestern institutions and companies, and poster sessions showcasing student research. The symposium also includes industry panels and networking events, offering attendees the opportunity to engage with professionals from both academia and the private sector.

One of MMLS’s key missions is to support junior researchers. The symposium has traditionally provided free registration and housing for students, helping to lower financial barriers to participation. The NSF support was mostly spent on supporting the free registration and housing for student attendance, as well as giving out 15 poster awards. 

The impact of MMLS extends beyond the event itself. It serves as a hub for interdisciplinary collaboration, connecting experts from computer science, statistics, engineering, and related fields. Past attendees have credited MMLS with providing their first academic conference experience, emphasizing its role in shaping early-stage researchers’ careers.

As machine learning continues to transform industries and research fields, MMLS remains a crucial venue for advancing knowledge, building professional networks, and strengthening the Midwest’s role in AI and data science innovation.

 


Last Modified: 03/26/2025
Modified by: Ju Sun

The Midwest Machine Learning Symposium (MMLS) is an annual regional conference dedicated to fostering collaboration among researchers in the Midwest and beyond. MMLS 2024was held on May 2021 at the University of Minnesota Twin Cities campus, MN.The event attracted over 350participants, including graduate students, faculty, and industry professionals, providing a platform for discussing cutting-edge research in machine learning and data science, both foundational and applied.


MMLS features 4plenary talks by leading researchers, 20+invited talks by junior faculty and industrial researchers from Midwestern institutions and companies, and poster sessions showcasing student research. The symposium also includes industry panels and networking events, offering attendees the opportunity to engage with professionals from both academia and the private sector.


One of MMLSs key missions is to support junior researchers. The symposium has traditionally provided free registration and housing for students, helping to lower financial barriers to participation. The NSF support was mostly spent on supporting the free registration and housing for student attendance, as well as giving out 15 poster awards.


The impact of MMLS extends beyond the event itself. It serves as a hub for interdisciplinary collaboration, connecting experts from computer science, statistics, engineering, and related fields. Past attendees have credited MMLS with providing their first academic conference experience, emphasizing its role in shaping early-stage researchers careers.


As machine learning continues to transform industries and research fields, MMLS remains a crucial venue for advancing knowledge, building professional networks, and strengthening the Midwests role in AI and data science innovation.
